column4: Hi! If there's a fix in a new stable version of Cairo-Dock that's killing me, and the release is not yet available through Synaptic, would it be wrong to install that new release by hand? What's the best practice?
if you insist on compiling from source, use checkinstall: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/CheckInstall
I guess I should remove the old version first, right?
that would probably be a good idea :) that way, when you go to uninstall it once the ubuntu package is released, you won't have to worry about collisions
I think it would be ok if I use just remove, not complete remove, to save my config, plugins, etc... what do you think?
that depends on where they live. if you leave them in place, checkinstall might complain and fail, or it might just overwrite them.
would this method be more appropriate (the first described) http://www.glx-dock.org/ww_page.php?p=From%20the%20repository&lang=en
oh, there's a 3rd-party repository with the package you want? sure, that would be easier than checkinstall from source
wow, this is incredible.. I'm impressed with all this :)
hehe.. I just jumped from early version of an application that was unstable, buggy and no-good, with a stable, new release and I'm impressed that it actually *WORKS* now! LOL
you need to put the 'f' last
only that one, as you're essentially saying -f <filename>
